diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as fever, oral ulcers, leukopenia, proteinuria, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known as a joint disorder, RA can have systemic manifestations including pericardial effusion and can occasionally present with leukopenia and oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This is a rare autoimmune disorder that may present with features of two or more connective tissue diseases (like SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis) including oral ulcers, leukopenia, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the glands that produce tears and saliva, but can cause systemic problems like renal issues (proteinuria), leukopenia, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This rare disorder causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to symptoms such as oral ulcers, fever, and can sometimes present with proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: An infection of the heart valves which can cause fever, leukopenia, and in severe cases, lead to renal complications including proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: The virus can cause a wide range of symptoms and opportunistic infections that may lead to fever, oral ulcers, leukopenia, and renal complications such as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Viral Hepatitis
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types like hepatitis B and C can cause symptoms including fever and leukopenia, and in chronic cases, may lead to kidney problems manifesting as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.rationale: A type of blood cancer that can cause fever, oral ulcers, and leukopenia; depending on the subtype and progression, could also lead to kidney issues.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: This type of cancer that begins in lymphocytes can lead to symptoms including fever, leukopenia, and in advanced cases, organ involvement resulting in symptoms like proteinuria.

diagnoses: Tick-borne diseases (besides Lyme, such as Ehrlichiosis)
Viral infection (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Schizophrenia (in the context of psychosis, considering other systemic symptoms might indicate a complex presentation or differential diagnosis)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) associated autoimmune disease
Primary Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP) with secondary complications
Systemic Vasculitis with central nervous system involvement

diagnoses.name: Chronic Pain Syndrome
reasoning: Chronic back pain is a primary symptom.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
reasoning: Chronic back pain may suggest inflammation of the spine.

diagnoses.name: Spondyloarthritis
reasoning: Chronic back pain and basophilia could indicate an inflammatory process.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
reasoning: Chronic pain and possible immune dysfunction referenced by dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
reasoning: Dyslipidemia and vision issues can be complications.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
reasoning: Chronic pain and systemic symptoms like basophilia.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Eye Disease
reasoning: Vision difficulties and irritated eyes, possibly linked with autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Dry Eye Syndrome
reasoning: Directly correlates with symptom of irritated eyes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease can cause a wide range of symptoms including inflammation (fibrosis, lymphadenitis), as well as issues affecting the urinary tract and digestive system.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Another autoimmune disorder that might present with generalized symptoms including lymphadenitis, and can also affect the digestive system akin to gastroparesis symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, including the lymph nodes and lungs (fibrosis), potentially leading to symptoms like those described.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Cancer of the lymphatic system can cause lymphadenitis and sweats; it might also indirectly affect other systems of the body.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reason: A bacterial infection that might cause lymphadenitis and night sweats; it can also have systemic effects that might mimic some of the described conditions.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: The virus can cause generalized lymphadenitis and sweats among its early symptoms and, over time, can lead to a range of health issues including digestive and systemic problems.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis
diagnoses.reason: Although a symptom itself, it can be part of a broader systemic issue, potentially connected with fibrosis and digestive system effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Might present with a wide range of symptoms including night sweats, fatigue (not explicitly mentioned but inferred from the complexity and systemic nature of symptoms), and can be associated with immune dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.reason: While primarily affecting connective tissue, some types can impact the digestive system, potentially leading to symptoms akin to gastroparesis, and overall inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease combines features of several autoimmune diseases, potentially accounting for a broad range of symptoms including those listed.

diagnoses: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, which may cause complications such as blood clots. This condition may contribute to symptoms such as headaches and dizziness (from increased blood viscosity) and might indirectly affect sleep quality.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts. Sleep apnea could lead to non-restorative sleep and might also contribute to polycythemia due to chronic low oxygen levels in the blood during sleep.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses that lasts for more than 12 weeks. This condition could result in congestion and non-restorative sleep due to difficulties in breathing.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder that affects people of all ages and walks of life, which involves both obsessions and compulsions that can interfere with all aspects of life, such as work, school, and personal relationships.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Anxiety can manifest with physical symptoms such as increased heart rate and congestion due to stress. It can also severely impact sleep, making it non-restorative, and can contribute to or exacerbate obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: Depression can lead to sleep disorders including the experience of non-restorative sleep. It can also exacerbate feelings of tiredness and lead to changes in behavior, possibly including obsessive or compulsive behaviors as coping mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. Though traditionally not directly related to the described symptoms, complications from hemochromatosis can affect a variety of bodily systems, potentially leading to a wide range of symptoms depending on the organs affected.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing. It is a leading cause of chronic morbidity and mortality. It can lead to polycythemia due to chronic hypoxemia.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: Characterized by persistent and excessive worry about a number of different things. People with GAD may anticipate disaster and may be overly concerned about money, health, family, work, or other issues. GAD can contribute to symptoms like non-restorative sleep and obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A chronic, progressive condition in which the heart muscle is unable to pump enough blood through to meet the body's needs for blood and oxygen. Heart failure can cause fluid congestion and polycythemia due to decreased oxygen transport capacity.

diagnoses: Reactive Monocytosis (due to infection or inflammation)
Acute Chest Syndrome in Sickle Cell Disease
Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamin C or Vitamin K deficiency)
Secondary Polycythemia due to Hypoxia or Tumor Production

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation throughout the body, potentially affecting skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can vary and include rash, joint pain, and fatigue. It may lead to miscarriages due to antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies in the blood, leading to an increased risk of blood clots. This condition can cause recurrent miscarriage and is associated with systemic inflammation that might contribute to various hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause increased levels of basophils, which are a type of white blood cell. Symptoms may include fatigue, weight loss, and sweats.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system that disturbs the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. Symptoms can include sensory disturbances. Miscarriage rates are not significantly higher, but disease symptoms can be exacerbated during pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to a wide range of symptoms including fatigue, cold sensitivity, and potentially contributing to miscarriages. Thyroid dysfunction can also alter taste perceptions.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition can lead to neurologic and psychiatric symptoms due to its role in the functioning of the brain and nervous system, potentially affecting taste (dysgeusia) and causing physical sensitivities. Severe cases might indirectly contribute to reproductive issues.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that occurs when the body does not have enough iron, leading to reduced red blood cell production. Symptoms can include fatigue and weakness. It has been associated with dysgeusia and could potentially impact pregnancy outcome.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder in which the body produces too many red blood cells. This can lead to thickened blood and increased risk of clotting. Symptoms include tiredness, itching, and heightened sensitivity to temperature. Miscarriages can occur due to increased blood viscosity and clotting abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets — the cells that help blood clot. Miscarriages can occur in severe cases due to the body's inability to form clots effectively.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Symptoms can vary and include gastrointestinal problems, dermatitis herpetiformis, and iron-deficiency anemia. The disease can affect pregnancy outcomes and may feature hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: CVID is a disorder characterized by low levels of several immunoglobulin classes, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. Patients may also exhibit symptoms like fatigue and can have autoimmune disorders that might present as easy bleeding or attention issues due to the chronic nature of their condition.

diagnoses.name: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare X-linked recessive disease characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count leading to easy bleeding), immune deficiency, and blood cancer risk. Attention deficit and hyperactivity can occur as secondary symptoms due to the overall stress and complications of managing a chronic disease.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This is the most common primary immunodeficiency, often asymptomatic, but can be associated with autoimmune diseases, allergies, and recurrent infections. While it might not directly cause attention deficit or hyperactivity, the associated conditions or repeated infections could impact a patient’s behavior and cognitive functions.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgM Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Characterized by normal or elevated levels of immunoglobulin M (IgM) with absent or significantly decreased levels of other immunoglobulins. This condition can lead to recurrent infections, and patients may present with symptoms like easy bleeding due to associated low platelet counts or autoimmune phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition causing repeated episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). While it doesn't inherently cause attention deficits or hyperactivity, the chronicity and management of the condition, and its complications, can impact patient quality of life and mental health.

diagnoses.name: Ataxia-Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that affects the nervous system, immune system, and other parts of the body. It is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasias, chronic sinus and lung infections, and an increased risk of malignancies. Immune deficiencies including decreased immunoglobulins can be part of its presentation, indirectly affecting cognitive aspects like attention.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder where white blood cells cannot properly destroy certain bacteria and fungi, leading to chronic inflammation and granuloma formation. While it primarily affects the immune system, the chronic inflammation can theoretically have neurological impacts, though clear links to attention deficits or hyperactivity are not directly established.

diagnoses.name: DiGeorge Syndrome (22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A disorder caused by a defect in chromosome 22, resulting in poor development of several bodily systems including the immune system. It can present with a broad range of symptoms including congenital heart defects, specific facial features, and learning disabilities or behavioral issues such as ADHD.

diagnoses.name: X-Linked Agammaglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects primarily males, caused by a mutation in the gene necessary for the development of B-cells, leading to an almost complete lack of immunoglobulins. Patients typically present with recurrent bacterial infections; however, the disease itself does not directly cause attention deficit or hyperactivity but can affect overall health and development.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgE Syndrome (Job's Syndrome)
diagnoses.description: Characterized by high levels of IgE, eczema, and recurrent skin and lung infections. Patients can also have various autoimmune manifestations. While primarily affecting the immune system and skin, the constant battle with infections and dealing with a chronic condition can indirectly affect a patient’s focus and activity levels.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, vertigo, headache, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage. They are caused by a temporary decrease in blood supply to part of the brain, which may cause symptoms such as weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraine is a powerful headache that often happens with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light. Some people also experience scintillations or aura, such as visual disturbances or temporary vision loss, which can be accompanied by vertigo and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending upon its location, it can cause weakness, headache, seizures, vertigo, aphasia, and vision disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS blocks the messages between your brain and body, leading to symptoms such as weakness, vertigo, headache, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Certain types of epilepsy present with vertigo, aphasia, and visual scintillations.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency occurs when there is reduced blood flow to the back part of the brain, which controls balance and coordination. Symptoms may include vertigo, dizziness, headache, and, in severe cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: Meniere's disease affects the inner ear and can cause vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and the feeling of fullness in the ear. Although weakness and headache are not primary symptoms, they can occur as secondary effects of the vertigo and overall distress.

diagnoses.name: Posterior Circulation Stroke
diagnoses.description: A posterior circulation stroke affects the back part of the brain and can present with vertigo, double vision, swallowing difficulties, headache, and sometimes weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Migraine
diagnoses.description: Vestibular migraine can cause vertigo, headaches, and other symptoms of migraine without the severe head pain. It's a variant of migraine where vertigo can be a dominant symptom along with light sensitivity, aura, and sometimes aphasia.

diagnoses: Demyelinating Diseases of the Central Nervous System

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent headaches that are moderate to severe. Typically, the headaches affect one half of the head, are pulsating in nature, and last from a few hours to 3 days.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a sudden reduction of vision in the affected eye, pain with eye movement, and occasionally, symptoms such as photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. It can cause temporary loss of vision, weakness, numbness, and paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include headache, fever, and a stiff neck, along with photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can lead to anemia and neurological disorders. It may cause symptoms of weakness, fatigue, numbness, and tingling in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms such as headache, weakness, seizure, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision depending on its location.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Drug Reactions (e.g., Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis)
Lupus-like syndromes due to genetic complement deficiencies
